sub_topic: Using the unit circle to find trigonometric values
message_1: Find the exact value of cos(pi/6) using the unit circle.
message_2:
Using the unit circle, we know that the coordinates of a point on the circle are given by (cos(θ), sin(θ)), where θ is the angle measured in radians.

When θ = π/6 (which is equivalent to 30 degrees), we can use the properties of a 30-60-90 right triangle to find the exact value of cos(π/6).

In a 30-60-90 right triangle, the side lengths are in the ratio 1:√3:2. The hypotenuse is the longest side (2), and the side adjacent to the 30-degree angle (π/6 radians) is the shortest side (1).

So, cos(π/6) is the ratio of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse:

cos(π/6) = 1/2
